Message.Title: Alibaba May Be Valued at $200 Billion by 2014 After IPO
Message.Msg: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd., China’s largest e-commerce company, may have a market value of as much as $200 billion by the end of 2014 after an initial public offering, said Carl Huttenlocher, chief investment officer of hedge-fund company Myriad Asset Management Ltd. SoftBank Corp. (9984), a Tokyo-based wireless carrier with a 35 percent stake in Alibaba, may see its market value boosted by as much as 75 percent as a result, according to Huttenlocher, whose Hong Kong-based company now manages $2.3 billion of assets. Alibaba may have an IPO this or next year that values the Hangzhou, eastern China-based company at as much as $100 billion, rivaling the $104 billion Facebook Inc. got at its May 2012 IPO (FB) price, analysts including Eric Qiu at Guosen Securities Co. have said. Facebook has a market value of $55.5 billion, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. Alibaba, which made founder Jack Ma a billionaire, will benefit from China’s expanding retail market, increasing use of Internet and smartphones, and a fragmented retail market, Huttenlocher said. Ma said last year that the company may go public within five years. “It’s much easier to gain share in a fast-growing pie,” he said at the first Karen Leung Memorial Investor Conference in Hong Kong yesterday. “The e-commerce market in China is an enormous and very fast growing market that we feel is also getting share from the offline retail market. Alibaba is the dominant company in the sector and has pricing power.” Internet Buying Retail sales in China are growing 14 percent a year, against 3 percent in the U.S., Huttenlocher, a former Asia head of New York-based Highbridge Capital Management LLC, said. About 42 percent of Chinese use the Internet now, compared with more than 80 percent in the U.S., he said. The top 20 traditional offline retailers in China command less than 10 percent of the market share, lower than the 40 percent to 50 percent in the U.S., he said.

Message.Title: Rumor: Alibaba Acquires Sogou
Message.Msg: TechWeb, 6/07/13 According to a post on the official microblogging account of Feng Dahui, Chief Technical Officer of online academic portal Dxy.cn, Chinese e-commerce conglomerate Alibaba Group has reached an agreement to acquire internet firm Sohu's (Nasdaq: SOHU) online search subsidiary Sogou. A spokesperson for Sogou denied the rumor, while Alibaba declined to comment.

Message.Title: Could Gap Up and Explode Monday
Message.Msg: Research Concurrent (CCUR) right away it could gap up and explode Monday. They just announced that they are doubling their quarterly cash dividend from $0.06 to $0.12 with their first $0.12 quarterly cash dividend being paid to shareholders later this month! This equals an annual dividend of $0.48 and CCUR closed yesterday at only $7.08 for an unbelievably HUGE dividend yield of 6.8%! According to Current Analysis, CCUR's Mediahawk VX video on demand (VOD) server technology just surpassed Cisco (CSCO)'s CDE 250 to become the #1 highest rated VOD product used by pay-TV companies! Over the past 4 quarters, CCUR's operating profit has increased from $187,000 to $413,000 to $876,000 to $1,233,000 for growth over the past year of 559%! CCUR's profits could continue to soar this quarter with the recent signing of a HUGE new deal with Virgin Media! CCUR's CDN technology is supporting their new Virgin TV Anywhere multi-screen service, which delivers linear and on demand TV to the smartphones and tablets of Virgin's 3.8 million subscribers! Last quarter, excluding share-based compensation and non-cash amortization, CCUR earned non-GAAP EPS of $0.16! This puts CCUR on track to earn non-GAAP EPS of $0.64 this calendar year! A P/E of just 20 to 30 based on potential full year non-GAAP EPS of $0.64 would make CCUR a $12.80 to $19.20 per share stock! CCUR is currently trading with an enterprise value of only 5 1/2X cash flow!

Message.Title: No Ads = Unrealistic Day Dreaming
Message.Msg: I am seeing lots of complaints by people who fear Tumblr will have more ads. I say wake up spoiled users! Get use to it, ads will be and always has been part of commercial websites. It's how they keep the lights on, pay the bills, bring home a paycheck, pay the mortgage and put food on the table for all the workers. People who demand no ads but enjoy the free service are the same people who will sit at Starbucks ALL DAY, moooch off their electricity to charge up their phone and laptop as they strategically place an empty coffee cup next to them. They also see nothing wrong with hijacking a table and chair from legit customers. These people have entitlement issues - No Ads is not the real reality. The world does not only revolve around YOUR blogging needs or your needs to see dogs on skateboards via YouTube with no ads. Companies cannot exist and will not exist with your "not for profit......what's in it for me mentality." It's just not financially feasible. Soooooo.......I'm all for Yahoo Ads. It will make the shareholders happy.....and pay the bills of the company. ; Ok, enuf of my ranting....just tired of all the whiners......wah wah wah!!!! On another note.....a great close today. I would not be surprise if some news will come out next week. My mantra is up to $40 and then $100. : Yeah go ahead....call me crazy.
